awd_titl_txt: Student Travel Support for the 2019 Association for Computing Machinery Conference on Knowledge Discovery and Data Mining (KDD 2019)
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant provides support for 20 U.S.-based graduate students to participate in the 25th Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) Conference on Knowledge Discovery and Data Mining (KDD 2019), to be held in Anchorage, Alaska, August 4 - 8, 2019. KDD is the world's premier conference in data science. It is a prestigious interdisciplinary conference that brings together researchers and practitioners every year, around 3,000 in the year, from all aspects of data science, data mining, and knowledge discovery. A strong representation of U.S. students and researchers is essential in maintaining U.S. competitiveness in this important area today and into the future. Since 2013, the KDD conference includes a Broadening Participation in Data Mining workshop. As in various STEM fields, increasing the diversity of participants in KDD research areas is a primary goal. The selection committee will select recipients of the support based on merit and need and place emphasis on diversity in the selection process. 

The KDD technical program includes oral and poster presentations of refereed papers, panel discussions, and invited talks by the world's leading experts. It provides an international forum for presentation of original research results as well as exchange and dissemination of innovative and practical development experiences, which are particularly valuable for student participants. Besides the technical program, the conference features workshops, tutorials, panels, posters, project showcases, a data mining contest (KDD Cup), social networks and job matching sessions, and a PhD forum. These events provide a comprehensive multi-faceted learning experience to students at all levels. Proceedings will be made available through the ACM Digital Library.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
KDD is a premier conference that brings together researchers and practitioners from data mining, knowledge discovery, data analytics, and big data. The purpose of the travel grants is to encourage students to participate in the exciting technical and other career enhancement programs at KDD as well as to increase diversity of the participants at the conference. Students, who might otherwise be unable to participate, have now the opportunity to attend sessions, tutorials, and workshops, meet other students and researchers from industry and academia, and take advantage of everything KDD has to offer!

This award was originally funded to support students' participation of KDD'19. We received 114 applications from US based students, in which 29 are female students and 85 are male students. In terms of their degrees pursued, 100 of them were PhD students, 9 were master students, and 5 were undergraduate students. Based on the planning in the proposal, we aimed to support 20 students with each of $1,000. The committee selected 20 awardees, in which 6 are females (i.e., 30%) and more than 4 other awardees are newcomers according to their applications. As planned, each student should get an award of $1,000, in which $500 covers the registration fee and up to $500 for their rest expenses like transportation and lodging. However, considering the overwhelming number of attendances (i.e., over 3000), the conference needs a substantial number of student volunteers. Therefore, SIGKDD decided to offer free registration to all student awardees so that they can support the conference as volunteers. This change was made in July, 2019, when all awardees have been finalized. Therefore, each student awardee was reimbursed up to $500 and 3 students were sent to Dr. Wei Wang to use up her remaining funding in IIS-1832544. In summary, 17 student awardees were reimbursed using this funding (i.e., IIS-1930821), where each student is reimbursed up to $500. 

Then, the remaining funding of $11,500 should be used to support students of KDD'20. However, Covid prevents the in-person attendance. KDD20 was a virtual conference and we offer registration awards (i.e., $50 each) to US based students. We received 135 applications from US based students. After review, we found that only 131 of them are valid and complete applications from US based students. Considering the sufficient amount of funding available to cover the registration fees for all these 131 students, we offer all of them the registration award, $50 each. However, 4 of them did not accept due to different personal reasons. Therefore, we officially offered 127 US based students the registration award, in which 43 (more than 30%) are female students and 84 are male students. In terms of their degrees pursued, 112 of them were PhD students, 4 were master students, 8 were undergraduate students, and 3 were high school students. It should be noted that during the application process, we received a letter indicating that three high school students have one paper accepted. However, they are not eligible for the registration award application, since they are high school students. After a discussion with the whole organizing committee, we agree that we should encourage high school students, since more and more high school students are entering the data mining community. Therefore, we offer these three high school students the registration award.

Thereafter, we still have a remaining amout of $5,150 and we decided to wait until the in-person conference happens again. Therefore, until KDD'22 that is in-person again, we were able to support another 7 US-based students (3 of them are female) for their in-person attendance of KDD'22.





Last Modified: 05/31/2023
Modified by: Juhua Hu
